data.title: Local Jewel
data.text:
Great to see beautiful flowers and good landscape.
A favorite place for a garden wedding.
A favorite place just to relax and contemplate.

data.title: A beautiful wedding venue
data.text: Our son;s wedding was recently at Gamble Gardens-the grounds were charming with many fantastic photo areas. The staff was so helpful There was a beautiful area for dining and the garden for the ceremony was perfect. It is definitely for a smaller wedding but if that is your choice we highly recommend this venue!

data.title: A pleasant break
data.text: Stop by and enjoy this small garden.  There's bound to be something in bloom and it's free.  There's also free parking.

data.title: A hiiden gem of tranquility in Palo Alto!
data.text: The Gamble gardens are definitely worth visiting. There is no admission fee, and for those who like history and gardening this is the perfect place. When we visiting in late July, there were only a few other visitors, and we mainly had the gardens to ourselves. The place is very well maintained, and the collection of plants, and flowers is amazing. I would recommend a visit.

data.title: Beautiful---Soothing
data.text:
I grew up in Palo Alto and my mother sill lives in the home that I spent my formative years. The Garden is an effort and collaboration by many volunteers. I have wheeled my mother through the gardens many times to view the beautiful flowers and shrubs. The Gamble home adjoins the Garden and is worth visiting and viewing.
There is no cost to visit the garden and it is wheelchair accessible.

data.title: Very Pretty Flowers
data.text:
This is a very nice garden which has a small free parking lot and is free to enter.  There are a lot of beautiful flowers here and some picnic tables.  A few ladies were enjoying their lunch at one of them.  We walked around for about 20 minutes and were able to see everything.  
Its a great place to stop by and enjoy nature.

data.title: Beautiful garden free to the public.
data.text: This attractive garden and house that was owned by a former Proctor & Gamble family member has a wide array of flowering plants, fruits and trees that Elizabeth Gamble cultivated.  It is free to the public.  Open during daylight hours.  Very serene and peaceful setting.  I saw many families taking graduation pictures and other photos.  They have done an excellent job of labeling the names of most of the plants.  I think it is wonderful that they have elementary schools involved in growing edible plants and donating them to the food shelter.  I will be back.

data.title: Wonderful community garden
data.text: Beautiful kept gardens and grounds surrounding historic old mansion of Gamble family. It's clear this is a treasured piece of land in Palo Alto. Serene and notable spot for locals to come take pictures of families and engagement photos, as well as pet photos!

data.title: Very Nice Place to Stop for a Few Minutes or Hours
data.text: I really enjoy stopping here when I am in Palo Alto.  It is very serene and beautiful.  It is very nice to see a large variety of plants whether they are native or not (large native area).  The flowers last weekend were absolutely beautiful.

data.title: Wonderful space for an event
data.text:
We were looking for a space for an event and we found the Gamble House and Garden.  I think they are know more for the beautiful space and garden but the house was perfect--great kitchen two nice large rooms and of course the wonderful grounds.  We were surprised at how much was blooming in early February.
And the staff was very helpful along with the list of people to provide services...they made us, all the way from Oregon, feel supported and welcome.

data.title: A little gem!
data.text: Beautiful gardens, free to the public.  Not a lot of land, but nicely prepared and displayed.  Free parking.  The Gamble house was closed for the holiday when I visited.  Check the website for activities.

data.title: 19th century again
data.text: If you had money in the late 1800s, you could live like this. The mansion is typical of the upper class "turn of the century" family. The garden was made to show off the family wealth since it obvilously took a full-time gardening staff to maintain. The grounds are segmented into different alcoves of related plants that are (of course) best viewed in the late Spring. A half-hour stroll can be relaxing. An hour is too much. Don't bringn the kids ... it will bore them.

data.title: Better later in the Spring, I'm sure, when the blooms come on
data.text: The primary purpose for my visit was birding, knowing that floral displays would be minimal at this time of year.  Even though the grounds are so well manicured that there is little cover for ground-loving birds, I did spot 18 species in the trees and bushes during the couple hours I spent there.  Folks in the office were very friendly. A pleasant morning's walk, if nothing else.

data.title: Gardens underwhelm
data.text: Not worth a drive- maybe a walk if you live nearby- certainly not a fly- very disappointing. Honestly with so many gorgeous gardens, from Stanfprd Shopping Center to Fiolli in Woodside, why go here?

data.title: Great local garden with an abundance of plants and lovely walkways
data.text: I live very close by but still enjoy taking out of town guesthere to enjoy the well maintained and lovely gardens that are well labeled. This is my go to place for photo shoots. I've taken many holiday portraits and recently took quite a few graduation photos here. It is also a great venue for craft shows, garden tours, and weddings. On a side note, the house is also very well maintained and my mother still remembers which room Elizabeth invited her to tea in. It is a great asset to the community and we appreciate the gifts that this place has to offer.

data.title: Nicely done gardens in old "estate" like setting.
data.text: Visited based on trip advisor recommendations.  This is a nicely kept up old styled garden adjacent to a historic house.  Setting is a quiet neighborhood and it is obvious the garden gets a lot of attention.  Our timing, November, was not conducive to seeing a lot of flowers but there was more than enough interest given the various separate garden areas to enjoy and get a few ideas.  Covered in roughly a 1/2 hour without being rushed.  No fee so the price is right.  Believe they give tours at certain times throughout the week although not on the day we were there.

data.title: Not friendly or welcoming
data.text:
I am interested in historic houses and have been to Gamble  house (i am from L A) a few times. So excited to find Gamble Garden.  I called and found out that they are open today.  The lady on the phone sounded friendly enough so i was excited to see it today, November 11, 2015. When we arrived, there weren't any signs to say enter here.  Ok.  Went into the house, a lady was talking loudly on the phone.  Found out later that she just came to tune the piano.  We wandered from room to room and heard yet another lady talking, this one was in the office with another lady behind the desk.  I said to the lady behind the desk, 'Excuse me, we are visiting.  And like to view the house.  How do we do that?'  I was thinking that there was information or a docent on site though their website said nothing about docents.  She said, 'you just walk around the first floor.' Wow, i have never been to a historic house that was run like this.  She didn't even say, hope you enjoy your visit.  I went back to the foyer and looked more closely at the literature they had out and found a one page write-up about the architecture of the house that you can not remove from the table.  They displayed a hardcover book for sale about the house and later i did find the book on a book stand in one of the room and read a lot of it. Must say the book is lightweight on historic info.  It would have been a better experience if there was a self-guided tour information sheet that gave more information about the house, about the left-over pictures on the wall, info on the fire places, pictures of the house in by-gone years ... Anything!  I would have been happy to make a donation or pay for a tour with some real information ... 

Instead, the only word i can think of the treatment i got was 'snooty'. At least it felt like that and that they really didn't care for you to come.    

The garden was nice.  You could apparently just come and have lunch or sit or stand or meditate.  It looked like a nice get-away. At least the plants were labelled.  But not much else.  I could have seen the same plants in a well stock nursery. 

For whatever fund raising or support the property got from the city or regular people, some of it could have been used to better serve people who came to visit the house.  Perhaps that was not the focus.  Like another reviewer said, maybe they just wanted to rent the place out for lavish events.  So disappointed! 

If you are not into using the grounds as a park... And you love history, you will feel cheated somehow of an opportunity to get in touch with Palo Altos' past, all because how poorly run this is.

data.title: Quiet Garden
data.text: Gamble is nice spot for a garden walk or picnic. It is small and fairly quiet in a very nice neighborhood in Palo Alto.

data.title: A welcome relief from precious overpriced Palo Alto
data.text: Palo Alto is kind of depressing, so full of chichi stores and places which would like to seem so. It is refreshing to come across this garden hidden in a pleasant suburban neighbourhood within reach of the main drag. We visited in fall when many of the blooms were faded but it was still a restful and unpretentious place, and local people do help to keep it going.  there's a nice mansion in the middle of the garden and you can wander round some of the rooms for free, it seems. At least we did. What the place is lacking is a coffee shop but it is nice that it is so low key. A bit of the old style Palo Alto which I remember dimly before all the tech money came flowing in.

data.title: Pretty gardens
data.text: Pretty, small garden good to take a stroll during the day. Of course there is a drought now so everyone is struggling in the garden areas.  They are doing some great work conserving water here.
